Always making careful decision taking into account her ability and resources, she had always been able to repay her loans on time. Her monthly earnings has always been around 150 USD. Recently, she started breeding cows to increase her income. Even though breeding cow take more time, it doesn't take as much energy as breeding pigs. Also, beef are currently in demand so she would like to take out a loan of 450 USD to buy another cow or two.

Translated from Vietnamese by Anh Hoai Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Năm nay 47 tuổi, chị Hồ Thị N. đã có hơn 10 năm trong việc chăn nuôi. Các năm trước chị thường vay vốn đầu tư cho việc nuôi lợn. Luôn chọn mức vốn phù hợp với khả năng nên chị N. chưa bao giờ gặp khó khăn trong hoàn trả. Thu nhập bình quân mỗi tháng của chị là 150USD. Thời gian gần đây, chị nuôi thêm bò để tăng thu nhập. Việc chăn nuôi bò mất nhiều thời gian hơn nhưng không vất vả như nuôi lợn. Vào thời điểm này bò đang được giá, chị N. làm đơn xin vay 450USD để mua một hoặc hai con bò. Chị N. hiện đang sống cùng chồng và 3 con. Chị là thành viên năm thứ 4 của Quỹ Tình thương

loans.use: Buy beeves

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., 51 years old, is a 4th year member of the TYM. She currently lived at Hung Nguyen with her husband and 4 children. Her family's income mainly come from growing rice and cattle-breeding. Before joing TYM, they used to borrow money from her relatives and local banks. The interest is so high that they never really have much money left after each payments. After joining TYM and paying interest at a much lower rate (and in longer term) her income has been more consistent. Her family's monthly income is about 200 USD. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 525 USD to buy more cows.

Translated from Vietnamese by Anh Hoai Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hiên, 51 tuổi, là thành viên năm thứ 4 của Quỹ Tình thương. Chị sống tại Hưng Nguyên cùng chồng và 4 người con. Hoạt động kinh doanh chủ yếu hiện nay của gia đình là làm ruộng và chăn nuôi. Nguồn vốn chăn nuôi lợn và bò được lấy từ gia đình và vay thêm ở bên ngoài. Trước khi có Quỹ Tình thương, chị Hiên thường phải vay từ những người cho vay tư nhân trong vùng. Lãi suất đi vay cao nên sau khi hoàn trả thường không có lợi nhuận. Từ khi tham gia Quỹ chị được vay vốn với mức lãi hợp lý, lại được chia nhỏ hoàn trả tuần nên kinh tế từng bước đi lên. Cho đến nay thu nhập bình quân hàng tháng của gia đình đạt 200USD/tháng. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 525USD mua bò về nuôi

loans.use: Buy cows

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kimombasa South D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence K.. She is currently in the business of produce sales and is requesting a loan to boost business. Florence is 35 years old and is married with a husband who buys and sells produce for work. She has 5 children ranging from age 3 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 25000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a house. Florence has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Florence is joined in her small group by Nulu Kauma, Milisa K., Nasimu K., and Ayubu K.. Nulu Kauma has a business running a restaurant and wants to add furniture. Milisa K. is currently operating a business running a restaurant and wants a loan to purchase more utensils. Nasimu K. operates a business selling produce and wants to add capital. Ayubu K. is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy and sell large quantities of produce

loans.name: Kimombasa South E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Fatina N.. She is currently in the business of produce sales and is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Fatina is 35 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from age 1.5 to 10 and most of her children go to school. Each week, Fatina makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Fatina has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Fatina is joined in her small group by Mwajuma N., Zainabu M., Prisca K., and Faridah M.. Mwajuma N. has a business trading produce and wants to add to her business. Zainabu M. is currently operating a business in produce sales and wants a loan to re-invest in her business. Prisca K. operates a business of selling clothes and wants to increase inventory. Faridah M. is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To trade large volumes of produce and increase profits

loans.name: Kimombasa South F Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Madina N.. She is currently in the business of selling cattle and is requesting a loan to expand business. Madina is 30 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 2 to 13 and her children go to school. Each week, Madina makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children. Madina has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Madina is joined in her small group by Joeria Namukobe, Zulaika N., Hadija M., and Hamida N.. Joeria Namukobe has a business in cattle trading and wants to diversify to selling goats. Zulaika N. is currently operating a business selling cattle and wants a loan to boost business. Hadija M. operates a business in cattle sales and wants to increase her inventory. Hamida N. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more furniture.

loans.use: To add more working capital to cattle trading business

loans.name: Ndifakulya East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Edisa B.. She is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling. Edisa is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a carpenter. She has 3 children ranging from age 4 to 14 and her children go to school. Each week, Edisa makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. Edisa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Edisa is joined in her small group by Haawa N., Zahara N., Fatuma N., and Haawa K.. Haawa N. has a business in charcoal selling and wants to construct a charcoal store and add more stock. Zahara N. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to add to her business. Fatuma N. operates a carpentry business and wants to boost business. Haawa K. is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair oils and chemicals.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal in large quantities

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ndifakulya East Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Fatuma M.. She is currently in the business of produce sales and is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Fatuma is 40 years old and is married. She has 8 children ranging from age 5 to 25 and her children go to school. Each week, Fatuma makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start a cattle rearing business. Fatuma has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Fatuma is joined in her small group by Saruwa M., Halima K., Sarah N., and Zai N.. Saruwa M. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to purchase in bulk. Halima K. is currently operating a business selling clothes and wants a loan to start a business selling shoes. Sarah N. operates a grocery store business and wants to purchase more groceries. Zai N. is currently in the business of making and selling snacks and is requesting a loan to purchase more ingredients like flour and cooking oil.

loans.use: To trade more produce and expand business

loans.name: Ndifakulya East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sulaina N.. She is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to rent bigger premises. Sulaina is 33 years old and is married with a husband who trades produce for work. She has 1 school going daughter aged 14. Each week, Sulaina makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land.

Sulaina is joined in her small group by Amina B., Aisha B., Justine Y., and Mariam K.. Amina B. has a business making and selling pottery and wants to add more capital. Aisha B. is currently operating a business in chicken trading and wants a loan to expand her business. Justine Y. operates a business selling charcoal and wants to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Mariam K. is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes.

loans.use: To expand restaurant business

loans.name: Ndifakulya East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jackline S.. She is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase a hair dryer. Jackline is 29 years old and is married. Her husband is a shop attendant. She has 2 children, aged 11 and 18, both of whom go to school. Each week, Jackline makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children.

Jackline is joined in her small group by Naster B., Jane N., Rehema K., and Grace K.. Naster B. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to expand to bulk selling. Jane N. is currently operating a business in poultry keeping and wants a loan to purchase poultry feed. Rehema K. operates a carpentry business and wants to purchase more timber. Grace K. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth fabric.

loans.use: To add to salon business

loans.name: Munakukama A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sarah K.. She is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan to add more capital. Sarah is 44 years old and is married with a husband who is a mansion builder for work. She has 8 children ranging from age 7 to 24 and her children go to school. Each week, Sarah makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Topista A., Alice N., Sarah N., and Nakato T.. Topista A. has a business selling fish and wants to increase the stock. Alice N. is currently operating a business selling maize and wants a loan to purchase more maize from the surrounding villages. Sarah N. operates a business selling tomatoes and wants to diversify to a fruit business. Nakato T. is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To expand brick business

loans.name: Rama

texts.en:
Rama T. lives in Khokhana Dobato, between Khokhana and Sainbu-Bhaishapati of the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are involved in farming and business.

Rama lives with her husband and children. Her husband, Sanu Raj T., went Saudi Arabia to work two years ago. Her daughter works in garment factory and her two sons are studying in grades 12 and 10, respectively.

Rama is a grocery shopkeeper. Her children also help in her shop. Due to the lack of money she can’t expand her business. So she is a loan to buy grocery items such as rice, maize, paddy and more.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for her shop

loans.name: Bimala

texts.en:
Bimala C. lives in Khokhana Dobato with her husband and two sons, and with her father-in-law and mother-in-law. Her father-in-law and mother-in-law are elderly and cannot work, while her sons are in grades 2 and 6.

Her husband, Sudip C., is a taxi driver. However, his income is not enough for them to run their family smoothly. So Bimala decided to work their land, growing seasonal vegetables. She sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening, every day. Now Bimala is requesting Rs 30000.00 (USD $475) to buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Nura

texts.en:
Nura P. is a 30-year-old wife and mother living in Khokhana Dobato of the Lalitpur district. She also lives with her father-in-law and mother-in-law. Nura's son and daughter are in grades 5 and 1, respectively. Nura's husband is in Saudi Arabia for work; he sometimes sends money, but not enough for them to meet household expenses. Her father-in-law doesn’t have work.

So Nura decided to open her own poultry firm. But due to lack of fund she cannot buy chickens for her firm. So Mrs Paiyar is asking for her first loan of Rs 10000.00 to buy small chickens. She hopes that she can at least meet the expenses of the education of her children from her income.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Bhyanti

texts.en:
Bhyanti M. is a 55-year-old widow living in Thecho, Lalitpur son, daughter-in-law and grandchild. Her husband, Ram M., died four years ago.

Bhyanti's daughter-in-law works in a garment factory and her grandchild is in primary school. Bhyanti and her son make different types of traditional icons. They have five years of experience, and make the icons according to the orders they receive.

Bhyanti is requesting a loan to purchase raw materials like wax and metal. In Nepal the cost of education is very high, and Bhyanti is planning on saving her income for her grandchild’s education.

loans.use: To buy raw material for her work

loans.name: Sarmila

texts.en:
Sarmila M. lives with her husband and two sons in Thecho, Lalitpur. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur. Her sons are in first and third grade.

Mrs. M. and her husband, Saroj M., make different types of traditional brass religious figures to the customer's requests. Due to the lack of money, they cannot meet the increasing demand of their customers. So Mrs. M. is requesting a loan to buy raw materials like wax and metal for her work.

loans.use: To buy raw material for her work

loans.name: Ram Kumari

texts.en:
Ram Kumari M. live in Thecho, Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming.

Mrs. M. lives with her husband and two children. Her daughter is in grade 4 and her son is only one year old. Her husband is Krishna M.; together, Mrs. M. and her husband opened their grocery shop seven years ago. They sell different types of grocery items in their shop. Due to lack of money they cannot purchase stock for their shop. So to expand their business Mrs. M. is requesting a loan to buy grocery items.

loans.use: To buy grocery stock for her shop

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is a living example of a dedicated, passionate, hard-working and successful businesswoman in the area of Alcaviejo, Los Alcarrizos in the city of Santo Domingo. She owns a clothing shop and she sells toasted bread with cheese or ham. She also sells natural juices and white and black coffee.

Damaris explains that she started her business a few years ago, and she was operating it in a pretty small locale in a very isolated place. After a period of efforts and sacrifices, she managed to move her business forward and get a better place close to the most of the community’s residents.

Damaris also thanks her lucky stars that she could finally have a son last year. “I’d been praying to God a lot to give me that precious a gift,” she says.

With her loan, the entrepreneur will buy clothing in bulk and raw materials to continue her businesses.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and bulk to restock her promising business.

loans.name: Angela María

texts.en:
Angela María is in her late fifties, and she lives in the area of Alcaviejo, Los Alcarrizos in the city of Santo Domingo. She has one twenty-year-old son. “I am married to the Lord,” she says to explain that she separated from her husband a couple of years ago, and that she had to raise her son on her own.

Angela owns and operates a clothing store which people visit every day to purchase new and used shirts, skirts, pants, shoes and other goods. She’s been running her store for three years in a small rented locale. She explains that she’d like to have a more spacious locale and more funds to invest in her business in order to move her business forward and increase her revenue.

Angela stresses the importance of good education, and says she’ll keep working hard to cover her educational expenses (she’s finishing last year of college) and support her son’s university studies.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing in bulk to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Colorina's Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Colorina A.. She is currently in the business of bread-baking and is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying ingredients. Colorina is 47 years old and is married. Her husband works as a bookkeeper in a government office. She has 3 children ranging from age 14 to 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Colorina makes approximately 160 Sudanese pounds in profits. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to spend more to educate her children.

Colorina is joined in her small group by Grace A., Lusiyer K., and Hestela S.. Grace A. has a business in bread-making and wants to start baking different types of bread. Lusiyer K. is currently operating a business selling vegetables in the market and wants a loan to construct a shop. Hestela S. operates a business selling drinks and wants to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Jenifer's Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jenifer A.. She runs a home-based brewery and is requesting a loan to buy more ingredients. Jenifer is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a grinding worker. She has one child who is 13 years old, and her child goes to school. Each week, Jenifer makes approximately 70 Sudanese pounds in profits. She hopes to be able to spend the extra profits from her loan on her child's education.

Jenifer is joined in her small group by Hellen A., Elezabeth E. and Agustina L.. Hellen A. has a brewery and bread-making business and wants to expand both of these business. Elizabeth E. is currently operating a business selling maize and beans in the market and wants a loan to expand the business. Agustina L. operates a brewery and wants to buy brewery containers and more ingredients.

loans.use: Buying more ingredients.

loans.name: Heam

texts.en: Mrs. Heam Y., 35, is a mother of two children and works as a construction laborer in Phnom Penh city, making on average of $4 a day of profit. Her husband also works at the construction site earning about $3.50 a day. Because of big concerns with their low daily income, this couple has decided to open another business with a  loan from Kiva to be used to purchase a plot of land for farming. They strongly believe that growing rice will increase their revenue and lead to increasing the standard of living for their family. They thank for your help.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land for farming.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mei

texts.en: Mrs. Mei S., 32, fishes for a living together with her husband. After catching fish they sell their catch in the market to earn approximately $10 a day of revenue. They have four children, one of who is a laborer with a salary of $70 a month. This couple aims to purchase a new motor for their boat and fishing equipment such as nets. This will help them catch more fish to sell in the market and increase their income.

loans.use: This couple aims to purchase a new motor for their boat and fishing equipment such as nets.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Hach

texts.en: Mrs. Hach S., 25, is married with one child. She works selling a variety of groceries in the market and earns about $2 a day of profit. Her husband works as a construction worker building houses and normally earns around $5 a day. She plans to use this loan to purchase more grocery products to sell in large quantity. This will increase her family’s income and allow her to save for the future.

loans.use: She plans to use this loan to purchase more grocery products to sell in large quantity.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nhom Chi Yen- Vong Nguyet - Tam Giang Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Yen, 39 years old, is the president of her town's women's union. Not only a frequent participant of community activity, she is also a very good worker. She took out a loan before with Binh Minh CDC to breed poultry. The income was used to help out the family as well as pay for her children's schooling. Her family's earning is roughly 130000 Dong per day. Mrs. Cuc need this loan to buy breed-pigs. Mrs. Thao would like to take out a loan to buy foodstuff for her farrow of ducks while Mrs. Tam need money to buy more hens. Similarly, Mrs. Toan and Mrs. Binh both need money to buy cattle-feed while Mrs. Hue is going to use this money to open a bicycle repair shop. Mrs. Xuan will help her husband with breeding pig. Last but not least, Mrs. Viet would like to start her own recycling business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Anh Hoai N., Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Yến, 39 tuổi là đội trưởng phụ nữ của thôn. Chị không những làm công tác xã hội tốt mà còn là một người tăng gia sản xuất giỏi. Chi vay 2006000đồng từ chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc để chăn nuôi gà tạo thu nhập cho gia đình, phục vụ hai con đang đi học. Mức thu nhập của gia đình chị khoảng 130000đồng/ngày. Chị Cúc vay để mua lợn giống. Chị Thảo vay để mua cám cho đàn vịt đẻ trứng. Chị Tám vay vốn để mua gà tăng gia sản xuất. Chị Toàn vay vốn để mua cám cho lợn. Chị Huệ vay vốn để mở cửa hàng sửa chữa xe đạp. Chị Xuân vay vốn cho chồng ở nhà chăn nuôi lợn. Chị Bình vay để mua cám chăn nuôi lợn. Chị Việt vay để mua bán đồ sắt vụn.

loans.use: Mua cám chăn nuôi, đi chợ đồng nát, mở cửa hiệu

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mr. Keo H., 46, has a business milling rice for the local farmers with his rice grinding mill to take the husks off the rice. He also recharges the batteries belonging to people in this community using a generator. In rural areas, people depend on these batteries to power their lights, TV, etc. He earns around $7 a day. His wife works as a teacher and makes on average about $1.60 a day. This couple has five children, one of who works making noodles, earning on average $6 per day. The rest of the children are students. They plan to use this loan of $1100 to purchase a new generator to replace their old, unreliable generator. This will allow them to charge more batteries in the village. Part of the loan will also help finance the purchase of a motor bike.

loans.use: To purchase a new generator to replace their old, unreliable generator.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Chi's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Chi has two children who are still going to school right now. In her free time, she usually participate in social activities of her town and district. Outside of communities work, she also breed poultry to increase family income in order to fund for her children to go to school. Her family earning is roughly 150,000 Dong per day. Mrs. Luyen, Mrs. Tuyen and Mrs. Lan all want to take out a loan to breed pig. Mrs. Bon need this loan cycle to buy foodstuff for her hen. Everyone in the group joined Binh Minh CDC (Kiva partner) because of they are allowed to pay in small payment for a longer time.

Translated from Vietnamese by Anh Hoai N., Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Chi có 2 con đang còn đi học. Chị thường xuyên tham gia công tác xã hội của thôn, tổ. N.ài công việc đoàn thể, chị còn chăn nuôi tăng gia săn xuất để có thêm thu nhập nuôi các con ăn học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị là 150000đồng/ngày. Chị Luyện và Chị Tuyến vay để chăn nuôi lợn. Chị Lân vay để mua lợn giống. Chị Bốn vay để mua thức ăn cho gà đẻ trứng. Cả 5 chị đều rất thích tham gia chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì được vay lâu dài và chỉ cần trả góp hàng tuần với số tiền nhỏ.

loans.use: Chăn nuôi

loans.name: Thi Thoa's Group

texts.vi:
Ms. Hue, 30 years old, has two children who are still in school. Everyday, besides farming, she goes to the market to collect recyclables, with the hope to increase her family income. On average, her family income is about 100,000VND a day (roughly $6.25 per day). Ms. Hue has introduced Ms. Thoa, 31 years old, about microcredit offered by Binh Minh cdc (Kiva Partner in Vietnam), where borrowers who do no need to have so much collaterals can still borrow money. Microcredit by Binh Minh is also good for them because the will not need to go far away to repay their loan. Ms. Thoa then also wants to borrow money to collect metal recyclables, which she hopes will increase her famiy's income. Together, they propose to borrow 275USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Huế, 30 tuổi, có hai con đang đi học. Ngoài việc chăm lo công việc đồng áng, chị còn đi chợ sắt vụn hàng ngày để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Thu nhập trung bình của gia đình chị khoàng 100000 đồng/ngày. Chị vay 2006000 đồng để thêm vốn đi chợ. Được chị Huế giới thiệu và tuyên truyền những lợi ích thiết thực mà chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminhcdc đem lại như không phải thế chấp sổ đỏ và đi lại xa xôi để trả tiền, chị Thoa, 31 tuổi, cũng vay vốn để đi chợ sắt tăng gia thu nhập.

loans.use: to collect metal recyclables

loans.name: Thi Hang

texts.vi:
Mrs Hằng is 39 years old. She sells vegetables and also raises pigs to increase her income. She is married and has 2 children: one is in the work force and the other one still goes to school. Due to irreconcilable differences, she and her husband had divorced. She has become the sole bread winner in the house so she has to work hard to raise her 2 children. To help their mother, the older child has quit school and works to gain money. Despite her difficult living condition, she has never borrowed money. She has applied to SEDA for a loan of 2006000 VND to buy pigs for breeding.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hằng, 39 tuổi, buôn bán các lại rau củ quả, ngoài ra chị còn chăn nuôi lợn để tăng gia săn xuất. Chị đã kết hôn và có hai con, 1 đứa đã đi làm còn 1 thì đang đi học. Do không hoà hợp nhau, hai vợ chồng chị đã li hôn. Hiện nay, một mình chị phải vất vả làm ruộng, buôn bán để nuôi hai con. Để giúp đỡ mẹ, một đứa con chị đã nghỉ học để đi làm thợ. Tuy khó khăn vất vả nhưng chị chưa từng vay vốn ở đâu. Chị tham gia vay 2006000 đồng của chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc để mua lợn giống.

loans.use: buy pigs to for breeding

loans.name: Thi Hao

texts.vi:
Mrs Thuyên is 54. She works as a farmer and raises pigs. She lives with her son and his wife, they are both skilled woodworkers. Her family income is 200000-300000 VND a day (~12.50 - 18.85 usd a day). She would like to borrow 2006000 VND to buy pig mash. She likes to borrow from SEDA because it does not require collateral, the loan officers are nice and helpful. They even go to her house to distribute the loan.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Thuyên, 59 tuổi, làm ruộng và chăn nuôi lợn. Chị sống cùng con trai và con dâu đều là những thợ mộc lành nghề của thôn. Thu nhập gia đình chị từ 200000-300000đồng/ ngày. Chị muốn vay 2006000 đồng để mua cám cho lợn ăn. Chị rất thích vay vốn của chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì không phải thế chấp, cán bộ tín dụng lại rất thân thiện, hướng dẫn tận tình, lại xuống tận nơi để thu phát vốn, chị không phải đi xa vất vả nữa.

loans.use: buy pig mash

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van S., 44, is a vendor of a variety of grocery products and makes on average about $3 a day. Sometimes she helps her husband to refine sugar. Her husband supports the family by working as a palm tree climber, climbing up bamboo poles to tap the sap of  trees to boil and make palm sugar. Everyday he collects palm sap and refines it to sugar to sell in the market and earns around $8 a day of income. They have five children, one of who is married and lives away from the family. Two of their children contribute to the family’s income by working to collect palm sap with their father and one of their daughters is employed by a garment factory in Phnom Penh, earning a salary of $60 a month, the majority of which she sends home. In order to improve the family’s living conditions and give their younger son a better education, this couple is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a plot of land to farm in the dry season. The farm will give them a long term, stable source of income.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to farm in the dry season.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Lan

texts.vi:
Mrs Lan is 40 years old. She would like to obtain a loan to buy a cow. She works in her rice field and sells basic goods at the market. Her family also works in carpentry. Her family income is 150000-200000 VND a day (9.50 - 12.50 usd) which is just enough to cover the daily expenses and provide education for their 4 children. She likes the loan condition of SEDA, since she sells basic goods at the market, it provides her with cash flow so it will be easy for her to make the weekly payment.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Lan, 40 tuổi, vay vốn để thêm tiền mua bò. Ngoài ra chị còn đi chợ, làm ruộng, gia đình chị còn có nghề phụ là làm thợ mộc, vì vậy thu nhập gia đình chị từ 150000-200000đồng/ngày, đủ để trang trải cho cuộc sống 2 vợ chồng và nuôi nấng 4 đứa con. Chị rất thích vay vốn của chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì chị đi chợ nên có thu nhập hàng ngày luôn và như vậy rất dễ để trả tiền theo tuần.

loans.use: buy a cow

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea N., age 30, is a vendor of grocery products, earning around $10 of income per day. Her husband Mr. Soy Tor works as an assistant clerk for the local government in his village and makes approximately $2 a day. This couple has three children, all of whom are students. They need to pay for their children’s schooling, especially the extra classes in the afternoon that helps them pass exams. She plans to use the loan to purchase more grocery products to sell as she now has high customer demand. She will also buy a water pump and fertilizers for their small plot of farmland.

loans.use: She plans to use the loan to purchase more grocery products and a water pump and fertilizers.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Bich

texts.en: Mrs. Bich S., 22, works as a rice broker, purchasing rice in bulk from farmers and reselling it for a profit when the price in the market rises, making on average around $6 a day. Her husband (pictured in photo)  works as a taxi-driver in Kampong Chhnang province and earns around $6 a day. She would like to borrow $1000 to increase the amount of rice she can buy in bulk and resell. This will increase her profit margin as well as raise her income since she gets a bigger bulk discount the more rice she buys. In the future they plan to buy a truck to transport the rice using the savings from her increased income.

loans.use: She would like to borrow $1000 to increase the amount of rice she can buy in bulk and resell.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Khair Mohammad

texts.en: Khair Mohammad lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and his wife is a teacher. He is supporting all of his family. Has a metal shop and this is the second years that he has been involved in this business. He wants to expand his business so he has requested an individual loan to complete his materials to attract more clients and make a good income to help his family. He is happy that he can improve his business.

loans.use: To complete his materials

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mrs. Kong S., 37, is a housewife who stays at home cooking food and looking after the children. Her husband supplements the household income by working as a motor-taxi driver, earning on average around $3 a day of profit. This couple has two children, one of who works in Phnom Penh as a garment worker. They would like to request a loan from Kiva to fix their motorbike which is the family's main source of income. Part of the loan amount will also help to purchase wood to strengthen their house. In the future, when they retire, they plan to open a small business breeding pigs, chicken, duck and so on.

loans.use: She will use this loan to fix a motorbike and purchase wood to strengthen her house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Puth

texts.en:
Mrs. Puth M., 59, raises pigs and sells porridge, earning approximately three dollars a day. Her husband is a garment worker and earns about three dollars a day. They have seven children, two of whom are employed by a garment factory earning two dollars each per day.

With this loan she will purchase more pigs to increase the number that she can breed and sell. She will also purchase a motorbike to deliver her porridge and help her husband and daughters commute to work. This will save expenses because the cost to hire a motor-taxi for the children to get to work each day is quite expensive .

loans.use: To purchase more pigs for breeding and purchase a motorbike.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Pol

texts.en:
Mrs. Pol C., 44, is married with five children and stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for her entire family. Her husband works as blacksmith and makes around $25 of revenue. Three of their children assist with their father’s work and two others are students.

To increase the growth of the blacksmith business, the family must purchase additional blacksmith tools. This loan will help them to increase the income of their family and which will help finance their younger children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase additional blacksmith tools.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yun S. V., 26, is a mother of three children and works as a garment worker, normally earning around two dollars a day. Her husband collects recycled items in the community and resells them to the recycling plant, earning about three dollars a day.

This couple will use this loan to purchase recycled items in bulk to lower their costs. (Mrs. Yun S. V. is not available for picture, husband only).

loans.use: To purchase recycled items in bulk.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mohammad Khan

texts.en: Mohammad Khan lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is educated and married. He was in Iran for about 6 years. When he came back 2 years ago, he decided to start a business. He opened a retail shop. Since then, he has attracted more clients in Kabul. Now he wants to enlarge his shop, so he requested an individual loan to complete his stock. He wants to make a good monthly income to help his family and make a good life in Afghanistan. He is happy with all parts of his family.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Ong

texts.en:
Mrs. Ong S., 54, sells beef and fish at an open-air market earning approximately five dollars per day. Her husband supports the family by raising pigs and cows which occasionally supply his wife’s butchery stand.

The couple has four children. The oldest is an English teacher with a salary of $30 a month; the second oldest helps sell beef and fish in the market; the third in line is employed by a garment factory earning $60 a month; the other child is a student.

Mrs. Ong S. has humbly applied for a loan to purchase more oxen to increase her family’s livestock. This will increase her inventory and her family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase more oxen to increase her family’s livestock.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mach

texts.en:
Mrs. Mach T., 44, is a farmer and earns about one dollar a day. Her husband runs a motor-taxi as a business earning approximately two dollars a day. The couple has three children. Two are students in Phnom Penh while one stays at home to help with the farm.

Mrs. T. plans to purchase another motorbike for the son who stays at home so he can start a business as a motor-taxi driver.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and start a motor-taxi business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mrs Im S., 49, is a housewife and raises pigs, making on average $1.50 a day. Her husband supports the family by working as a logger, making about one dollar a day. The couple has seven children. Three children are married and live outside the family home; three others work in a garment factory in Phnom Penh earning $70 a month; the last child is a student.

The loan will be used to purchase more small pigs to breed.

loans.use: To purchase more small pigs to breed

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Path

texts.en:
Mrs. Path M., 23, is a vendor at the market selling grocery products and desserts. She earns approximately $13 a day. Her husband supplements the household income by breeding pigs and helping his wife with her business. He earns about $7 a day. They have one young child.

Mrs. M. would like to purchase more pigs for breeding and purchase rice to sell at the market to increase the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs for breeding and purchase rice to sell at the market.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Path Mom and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Neema's Neema Group

texts.en:
Neema is 37 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, aged 14, 9, and 5. Neema owns a small shop, which she started in 2008. Every day she works from 7:30 AM to 8:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Neema now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has a business dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. Ros K. T., 40, is a housewife and her husband works as a construction laborer making approximately $3.30 a day. They have five children. The oldest is married and lives outside of the family home. Two children work in a garment factory and the others are students.

Mrs. K. T. will use this loan to start a business breeding pigs, chickens and ducks.

loans.use: To start a business breeding pigs, chickens and ducks

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ashura's Tusongembele Group

texts.en:
Ashura is 48 years old and is a widow with 7 children, aged 30, 26, 25, 18, 16, 13, and 12. She also takes care of 1 other person, aged 90. Ashura sells clothes and makes batiks, and she started her business in 2001. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 8:30 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

Ashura now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Thoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoun Y. and her husband married in 1974. They have eight children; three sons and five daughters. Four of the children have married. Three live in separate housing, one lives with them, and the younger four children are in school.

Mrs. Thoun has been a weaver for over forty years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who will take them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband grows rice and vegetables near the house. They live along the Mekong River about ten kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Thoun Y. is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $800 to purchase a motorbike for her son to use to run a motor taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for a motor taxi

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Mrs. Yen S., 32, sells food products, earning approximately two dollars a day. Her husband grows vegetables on a plot of land that he owns. He earns about two dollars a day. They have four children, all of whom are students.

The loan they are requesting will be used to purchase a water pump to water the crops.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump to water crops

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Subira

texts.en:
Subira is 49 years old and is a widow with 4 children, aged 32, 30, 27, and 21. She also takes care of 2 other people, aged 40 and 70. Subira is a fish seller, and she started her business in 2007. Every day she works from 7:00 AM to 8:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Subira now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Chamroen

texts.en:
Mrs. Chamroen T. and her husband, Novary YAB, married in 1978. They have six children: three sons and three daughters. One of the daughters has married; their eldest son is a teacher, the second son is a blacksmith, and the other three children are in school.

Mrs. Chamroen has been selling meals for fifteen years. Her husband has been a teacher for twenty-eight years. Their house is about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chamroen is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $1200 to purchase blacksmith's materials for her son’s business.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith's materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mr. Sophal H. (pictured with his wife) and his wife, Sreytouch SIN, married in 1996. They have two children: one son and one daughter, both of whom are studying in primary school.

Mr. Sophal is a taxi driver in Phnom Penh City. His wife stays at home taking care of their children. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Sophal is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $1000 for repairing his house.

loans.use: repairing their house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanahawa's Tujikwamue Group

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 48 years old and is a married woman with 5 children, aged 30, 27, 25, 20, and 8. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, aged 100 and 80. Mwanahawa is a tailor and a chips seller, a business that she started in 2007. Every day she works from 6:00 AM to 7:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Mwanahawa now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in a salon, drinks selling, and cloth selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Chrouk

texts.en:
Mrs. Chrouk T. (pictured with her husband) and her husband married in 1963. They have six children: four sons and two daughters. Five of their children are married and live outside the family home and the youngest son lives under their roof and helps them in doing farming.

Mrs. Chrouk and her husband have been doing farming for almost thirty years. They grow cucumbers and other vegetables on the farm near their home. They are in their early 60s but still strong enough to work. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chrouk is requesting a loan for the fourth time in the amount of $300 for growing cucumbers.

loans.use: growing cucumbers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary S. and her husband married in 1991. They have three children, one son and two daughters, all of whom are studying in primary school. The family lives about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mary and her husband have been selling clothes for twelve years. They buy them from the market in Phnom Penh for re-sale. Mary sells at her shop in Prek Kdam Market and her husband travels from place to place selling out of his car.

Mary is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $1000 to purchase more clothes for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia is 24 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, aged 7, 5, and 3. She and her husband also take care of 1 other person, aged 52. Asia sells popcorn, and she started her business in 2007. Every day she works from 10:00 AM to 8:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Asia now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Kay

texts.en:
Mrs. Kay P., 31, sells grocery products and beef, earning approximately three dollars a day. Her husband sells natural medicine from province to province and earns, on average, five dollars a day. The couple has four children, all of whom are students.

This loan will be used to purchase a market stand in a busy market.

loans.use: This loan will be used to purchase a market stand in a busy market.

loans.name: Johari's Nyota Group

texts.en:
Johari is 38 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, aged 14, 9, and 3. Johari owns a small stationery store, which she started in 2006. Every day she works from 9:00 AM to 6:30 PM at her business.

Johari now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food vending and charcoal selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Munakukama B Group

texts.en: The group leader of this small group is Babirye M..  She is currently in the business of selling maize and is requesting a loan to add to her business.  Babirye is 47 years old and is a widow. She has 7 children ranging from age 5 to 20 and her children go to school.  Each week, Babirye makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children and cater for her family.  Babirye has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.  Babirye is joined in her small group by Beatrice B., Okello K., Mawazi N., and Hawa M..  Beatrice B. has a business selling fish and tomatoes and wants to expand her fish business.  Okello K. is currently operating a drug shop business and wants a loan to add more stock.  Mawazi N. operates a business in tailoring and wants to purchase more cloth fabric.  Hawa M. is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair chemicals.

loans.use: To expand maize selling business and increase profits

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Mrs. Phan P., 36, works as a farmer and makes on average around one dollar a day. Her husband is a palm climber, collecting palm juice and refining it to sugar palm. He earns approximately three dollars in revenue. The couple has four children, all of whom are students but also help out on the farm.

This loan will be used to purchase another plot of farmland in order to increase yields and increase the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase another plot of farmland in order to increase yields.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Munakukama C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rebecca K.. She is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to purchase more tomatoes to sell. Rebecca is 47 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant farmer. She has 10 children ranging from age 5 to 28 and her children go to school. Each week, Rebecca makes approximately UGX 15000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in her business. Rebecca has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to add to her tomato business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rebecca is joined in her small group by Mirab K., Muhamad Z., Hafusa N., and Margret A.. Mirab K. has a business selling fish and wants to add more capital. Muhamad Z. is currently operating a carpentry business and wants a loan to stock more timber. Hafusa N. operates a business selling tomatoes and wants to boost business. Margret A. is currently in the business of fish sales and is requesting a loan to expand business.

loans.use: To purchase large volumes of tomatoes

loans.name: Ratha Chab's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ratha C. (pictured with her husband on the right) was selected to be the group leader for a loan from Maxima. The group includes four families, who live about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

1- Mrs. Ratha C. and her husband married in 1997. They have five children: two sons and three daughters. Three of their children are in school and other two still young and stay at home. Ratha has done laundry at her home for two years and her husband has been a construction worker for ten years. Mrs. Ratha is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $100 to purchase construction material for her husband.

2- Mrs. Sreynorn P. and her husband married in 2004 and have two little sons. Sreynorn is employed cutting grass for cows and her husband has been a construction worker for 7 years. She is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $100 to repairing her house.

3- Mrs. Sinoun L. (pictured with her daughter on the left) is a widow with six children: five sons and one daughter. Her eldest son is a motor taxi driver; the second son cuts grass for re-sale; her daughter works in a garment factory, and the other three children are studying in local schools. Sinoun has sold lotus fruit at the market in Phnom Penh for two years. She is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $200 to replace an old trailer with a new passenger trailer for her son’s motor taxi business.

4- Mrs. Sreynet P. and her husband married in 2006 and have one daughter. Sreynet sells corn at the village market and her husband has been a construction worker for 6 years. She is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $100 to buy corn for re-sale.

loans.use: For purchasing construction materials, repairing a house, changing motor taxi trailer, and buying corn for re-sale

loans.name: Mariam's Nyota Group

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with 2 children, aged 12 and 7. Mariam is a clothes seller, and she started her business in 2006. Every day she works from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM at her business.

Mariam now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in a salon, tailoring, and charcoal selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

Each week, Jesca makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a goat for rearing. Jesca has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 20000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Jesca is joined in her small group by Jackline N., Naume I., Sarah N., and Juliet A.. Jackline N. has a business in clothing sales and wants to increase stock. Naume I. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Sarah N. operates a retail shop business and wants to stock more shop items. Juliet A. is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling.

Chiku now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has a business dealing in clothes selling.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ben

texts.en:
Ben, age 40, is a businessman with both wholesale and retail shops in Busaana trading center. He has been our client for 3 years out of the 6 years he has been in busines. Ever since he started getting loans, things are better every day. From his savings, he has managed to build a maize factory in Busaana, which is also doing very well.

The plaster on his face is a result of an accident that happened on his way home from his duties, but to him, this is no hindrance, since he gets the treatment desired and above all, his wife is a good help. He needs a loan to recapitalize his shops by buying more soda, beer, sugar, salt and other essentials.

loans.use: To buy more soda, beer, sugar, salt and other essentials for his retail shop.

loans.name: Kyowamwino A Group

texts.en:

Her husband is a peasant farmer. She has 5 children ranging from age 2 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Jesca makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business.

Jesca is joined in her small group by Mary N., Julian A., Zabina K., and Jesca A.. Mary N. has a business selling fish and wants to invest in her business. Julian A. is currently operating a business selling tomatoes and wants a loan to start a business selling fruit. Zabina K. operates a business selling maize and wants to add more stock. Jesca A. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more raw food.

loans.use: To add capital to restaurant business

loans.name: Sitheavy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sitheavy R. and her husband married in 1985. They have two children, one son and one daughter. Both are studying. Their house is in a Phnom Penh suburb.

Mrs. Sitheavy and her husband have been in the business of selling groceries and renting houses to local workers. She buys grocery items from Chba Ampov Market for re-sale at her house.

She is requesting a loan for the first time in the amount of $500 to purchase more grocery items for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for re-sale

Every day she works from 6:00 AM to 4:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Marry now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food vending, cloth selling, and soap selling.

Mrs. E. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to commute to work and to make some house repairs.

Mrs. Savang has been a silk weaver for over forty years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother and now she also teaches her daughter to weave silk.

She is requesting a loan for the third time in the amount of $100 to purchase silk material for weaving.

Mrs. S. would like to request a loan of $1000 from Kiva to increase her inventory and lower her costs by purchasing her products in bulk.

texts.en: Mr. Trun P., 42, works as taxi driver and also rent his car to the customers. He earns around eight dollars a day. His wife supplements the household income by renting rooms to local workers making, on average, about two dollars a day. This couple has three children; one of whom is married. The two other children are unemployed. Mr. P. would like to request a loan of $1000 from Kiva to fix his car as it is the family's main source of income.

loans.use: To make car repairs

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Trun Pov start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

payments.comment:
Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian  entrepreneurs like Mok Phaly start and sustain their businesses. sincerely, 

Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Tunuh's Tunajiamini. Group

texts.en:
Tunuh is 26 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 14 years old and 6 months. Tunuh owns a small grocery store that she started in 2001. Everyday, she works from 6:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. at her business.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling batique selling, food, cloth and soap.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Leya Samuel's Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Leya S.. She is currently selling fish and beans and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Leya is 38 years old and is married with a husband who is a police man. She has 2 children ages 5 and 8 and her children go to school. Each week, Leya makes approximately 75 Sudanese pounds in profits. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land for a house.

Leya is joined in her small group by Lucia A., Floura J., Margret J. and Victoria P.. Lucia A. has a business selling bread and wants to expand the business. Floura J. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to expand. Margret J. operates a business of selling charcoal and wants to expand her business. Victoria P. is also in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC South Sudan - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kiyinki B1 South A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Halima N.. She is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Halima is 30 years old and is single. Each week, Halima makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business. Halima has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Halima is joined in her small group by Halima K., Sylvia Nbabazi, Fatuma N., and Rose N.. Halima K. has a business selling shoes and wants to purchase shoes in bulk. Sylvia Nbabazi is currently operating a business selling clothes and wants a loan to add more business. Fatuma N. operates a retail shop business and wants to add more commodities. Rose N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge.

loans.use: To increase inventory in clothing business

loans.name: Chon

texts.en:
Mrs. Chon C. L., 35, and her husband, Mr. He Hal, are rice farmer and fishers. She lives with her family in the village of the Svey Tadork in the province of the Siem Reap in Cambodia. They both earn about $7 a day. She has two children, one of whom is a student. The other is just a young child. Because of her business, she can pay her family’s expenses and pay for her children to go to school. Previously, she successfully concluded a loan with HKL for two cycles.

In order to upgrade her fishing business, L. is now asking for a loan of $1100 to buy fishing tools (nets and trap). She appreciates Kiva and promises to be prompt in repaying her loan.

loans.use: To buy fishing tools (nets and trap) to upgrade her fishing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase clothing in bulk to boost a small business.

loans.name: Sheraly

texts.ru:
Sheraly Rahmonovich H. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. He is 42 years old, married with no children. He has college education and is an engineer by profession. He works at the aluminum factory as a shift supervisor. He plans to use the loan to repair his apartment. This will allow Sheraly to improve his living conditions as his salary is not very large and is not enough to allow him to repair the apartment without a loan. He will be able to pay off the loan by small amounts within 9 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хисочаев Шерали Рахмонович проживает в городе Турсун-заде. Возраст 42 года. Женат детей не имеет. Образование высшее. По профессии инженер.Работает на Аллюминиевом заводе мастером смены. Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы отремонтировать свою квартиру. Это позволит клиенту улучшить условия жизни, так как его заработная плата не так велика, чтобы он смог отремантировать квартиру без помощи кредита.Получив кредит клиент сможет частично погашать кредит в течении 9 месяцев.

loans.use: To repair apartment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in an assortment of materials for a beauty parlor.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase of a wide range of goods to restock a small grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables to for a small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase of fruits and vegetables to expand a small business.

loans.name: Davlatbiby

texts.ru:
Davlatbiby Salimovna H. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. She is 44 years old, married and has four children. She also has a secondary education. She is in the retail business and has own vendor space on the market. She sells women's clothing which she brings in from Dushanbe (capital of Tajikistan) and buys it from wholesalers at a lower price and then resells at a more profitable price. She has been in this business for the past five years. Davlatbiby plans to use the loan to buy new seasonal merchandise which will provide the customers with clothing for the spring. Besides, the local residents will be able to purchase the necessary clothes without having to leave their town. She plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хаитова Давлатбиби Салимовна проживает в городе Турсун-заде. Возраст 44 года, замужем имеет 4 детей. Так же имеет среднее образование. Занимается бизнесом в сфере торговли.Имеет торговую точку на рынке.Продает женскую одежду. Товар привозит из города Душанбе, покупая у оптовых реализаторов по более низкой цене и перепродает у себя на рынке по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим бизнесом клиентка уже около 5 лет. Планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы завести свежий сезонный товар. Это позволит обеспечить рынок сезонным товаром. Кроме того население сможет покупать необходимые для себя вещи, не выезжая за приделы города. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase commodity turnover

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase raw materials to keep preparing food for her customers.

texts.en:
Zabibu is 30 years old and is a single woman. Zabibu owns a small grocery store that she started in 2004. Everyday, she works from 6:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

In the past, Zabibu has taken out a successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.ru:
Mahbuba Ergashevna N. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. She is 30 years old, married and has two children. She has secondary education. She is in the retail business and has own vendor space at the local market where she sells polyethylene. She brings in the products from Dushanbe (capital of Tajikistan) where she buys it from wholesalers at a lower price and then resells it for a more profitable price. This business is the main source of income for her family and it's important for Mahbuba to develop and expand it. Her merchandise is in high demand among the local residents. Polyethylene is used in farming and agriculture, such as in greenhouses, and that's why the development of the retail sector for this products allows to supply the markets with it. Mahbuba has been in this business for the past three years. She plans to use the loan to increase her commodity turnover and plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Нишонова Махбуба Эргашевна проживает в городе Турсун-заде. Возраст 30 лет, замужем имеет 2 детей. Имеет среднее образование. Занимается бизнесом в сфере торговли.Имеет торговую точку на рынке.Продает полиэтилен. Товар привозит из города Душанбе покупая у оптовых реализаторов по более низкой цене и перепродает у себя на рынке по более выгодной цене. Этот бизнес является основным источником дохода ее семьи, поэтому необходимо развивать ей свой бизнес.Кроме того продаваемый ею товар пользуется спросом у населения. Используют полиэтилен в сельском хозяйстве, для парников, поэтому развитие торговли данного вида продукции дает возможность обеспечить им (полиэтилен)рынки.. Занимается этим видом бизнеса 3 года. Планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase commodity turnover

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 26, 2008)

She has been in this business for the past five years. Zarbibi plans to use the loan to increase her commodity turnover. She plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Махмудова Зарбиби Давлятовна проживает в городе Турсун-заде. Возраст 51 год , замужем имеет 10 детей. Так же имеет среднее образование. Товар привозит из города Душанбе покупая у оптовых реализаторов по более низкой цене и перепродает у себя на рынке по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим видом бизнеса 5 лет. Планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

texts.en:

In the past, Gisela has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who sells fish.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Berena's Uchumi Group

texts.en:
Berena is a divorced woman. She has been selling bananas since in 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

In the past, Berena has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has a store.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.ru:
Gulnora Yusupovna H. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. She is 25 years old and not married. She has secondary education and is an entrepreneur. She is manufacturing candy "Pichak." The main ingredients of this type of candy is sugar and water. When the candies are ready she gives them for resale to market vendors. Gulnora has been in this business for about four years. Her products are very popular among the residents and this is why her business provides the opportunity to supply the markets with candy at affordable prices. She plans to use the loan to purchase and stock up with sugar because the prices tend to go up. This will allow to keep the price low for the product. Gulnora plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хайдарова Гулнора Юсуповна проживает в городе Турсун-заде. Возраст 25 лет ,не замужем. Образование среднее. Занимается предпринимательством в сфере производства. Готовит конфеты « Пичак» . Основными ингридиентами данного вида конфет является сахар и вода.После того как конфеты готовы клиентка отдает их на реализацию продавцам,на рынки.Занимается этим видом деятельности около 4 лет. Ее продукция пользуется успехом у населения , поэтому ее бизнес дает возможность обеспечить рынки конфетами по доступным ценам. Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы приобрести и запастись сахаром, так как цены на него растут .Это позволит удерживать цены на данную продукцию.Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy sugar

Victo is joined in her small group by Suzan N., Joyce N., Topista Namboozo, and Betty M.. Suzan N. has a business selling produce and wants to uplift her business. payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Rustamdjon

texts.ru:
Rustamdjon Rahmatovich A. lives in the Rudaki region. He is 32 years old, married with one child. He has a college education and is a pharmacist by profession. Currently he does not work as a pharmacist and is in the manufacturing and sales of sambusa (Tajik patties). At this time it's the only source of income for his family. Rustamdjon plans to use the loan to open a pharmacy. He owns a facility, but he needs the money to buy the medicine. This will help him work as a professional pharmacist and will provide the local residents with the opportunity to buy the drugs in their kishlak (village). Because medicine, specifically first aid, should be always readily available and there's not enough time to travel outside the village to buy them. Rustamdjon plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдусатторов Рустамджон рахматович, житель района Рудаки. 32 года , женат, имеет 1 ребенка. Имеет высшее образование ,по специальности Фармацефт. В данное время не работает по профессии, но занимается выпечкой самбусы и ее реализацией. Пока это единственный источник дохода его семьи. Планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы открыть аптеку. Клиент имеет помещение , но ему необходимы деньги для ввоза лекарств. Это поможет ему работать по специальности, кроме того дать возможность населению покупать лекарства у себя в кишлаке. Так как лекарства , особенно лекарства первой необходимости всегда должны быть доступны, потому что не всегда есть время выезжать за ними в город.Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To open a pharmacy and buy medicine

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Это поможет ему улучшить условия жизни для своей семьи, так как без кредита его заработная плата не позволит сделать ремонт.Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 14 месяцев.

She has been in this business for the past four years. She plans to use the loan to increase her commodity turnover by bringing in seasonal merchandise. She buys merchandise from wholesalers and resells in retail. She plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Рашидова Гулбахор жительница города Душанбе. Возраст 34 года, не замужем имеет одного ребенка. Имеет среднее образование. Занимается торговлей . Планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы увеличить товарооборот , путем ввоза сезонного товара. Покупает товар у оптовых реализаторов и перепродает в розницу. loans.name: Corazón De Jesús Group

texts.en:
Corazón D. Jesús is a small community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari-project. The bank provides credit and educational services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations because it's a cold and very mountainous area (with altituD. ranges from 6,000-17,000 feet above sea level), it's difficult to grow crops there, and it lacks an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR Corazón D. Jesús is located the community of Soccos in the Anco district of Churcampa province. The population's main activities are growing either corn (lower altitudes) or potatoes and wheat (higher altitudes), and raising guinea-pigs, pigs, and chicken. Soccos faces many difficulties due to its remoteness, lack of public transportation, and access to markets, and receives very few public and social services.

The bank has completed its first loan cycle in just half a year of existence. A total of 3,600 soles (about $1,240.00) has been loaned to nine women. The loans range from 100, 200, 400, and 600 soles and, in one case, 1,000 soles. The group was also able to save over 1,700 soles (about $590.00) in this first cycle and will continue to save in the future.

During their first cycle, the members have learned to love and value themselves as people. They have learned–sometimes for the first time in their lives–to save, and have received some training about how to improve the quality of their lives. Most members have small grocery stores or sell at local weekly markets, but every member has a different testimony.

Dora Z. D. C. runs a small grocery store and also sells ice-cream. With her loan of 600 soles, she will buy new supplies for the store. When asked about her future, she says that she wants to improve her small store and that everything she earns and saves is for the education of her children so they can keep studying and become professionals. She is saving to buy a glass showcase for her products and more items to sell.

María Soledad Q. M. buys and sells fruit at small, local weekly markets. She also has a small field where she produces pacay, oranges, and lime-fruits. And, if it's not enough, she buys and sells tara and cochinilla, which she takes to the markets as well. With her loan of 600 soles she will be able to buy more fruit to sell. With her savings she wants to improve her business, send her children to school, and make improvements to her house.

Lucia S. S. has the smallest loan of the group (100 soles) and runs a small business buying and selling animals like pigs. Sometimes she sells the meat of cows or bulls in Soccos or one of the local fairs. She also has some terrain where she cultivates corn, potatoes, wheat, barley, and olluco. But most of the production is for auto-consumption. Lucia’s dream for the future is to buy a bull (improved) to use to raise cows. And, like all the women, her dream is for her family--to improve their quality of life and for her children to go to school. She will use her savings to buy school supplies because a new year is starting. Lucia says she has also learned some specific things in FINCA. She learned to say sorry and not fight over small issues, she learned not to gossip, not talk badly of someone, and to be more calm when talking with her husband and children.

loans.use: To buy new supllies
